title: Find the Sources You Need
description:
Learn where and how to find books, articles, and more! We’ll break down the differences between primary and secondary sources; when to use books vs. newspapers vs. scholarly journals vs. the internet; and share search strategies so you are locating sources smarter (not harder). Perfect if you’re new to college-level research or just want to sharpen your skills before your next assignment. 
 
 Related LibGuide:  Introduction to Research by Drew Wallace 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/15799411

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Visual Arts Thesis Exhibition: The Shape of Becoming
description:
Celebrate the end of the semester with a brilliant showcase from our rising Visual Arts graduates! This exhibition marks the culmination of their degree with each student presenting a cohesive body of artwork in the Finley Galleries, our final exhibition of the Fall 2025 semester. 
 The Shape of Becoming  features an impressive range of fresh perspectives and approaches: mixed-media sculpture, large-scale painting, textiles, video projection, and large-scale installations. 38 Visual Arts graduates invite you to explore their creative research and the questions driving their practice, on view through these vibrant capstone projects! Visit the gallery and join us on Wed Dec 17 at 6pm to meet the artists at the closing reception and awards ceremony. 
 Exhibiting Artists: Section 1: Edwin Acevedo, Kyle Bednarz, Nicholas Chong, Caitlin Danton, Maria Sophia De Los Reyes, Eve Gada, Henry E Garcia, Danae Higdon, Dan Mcguigan, Gianna Morel, Eduardo Valera Rodriguez, Victoria Takach 
 Section 2:  Ilaria Cangialosi, Melanie Carlos, Sean Coleman, Katherine Colon, Vincent Dinnocenzo, Syd Goldstein, Ruoya He, Prince Quincy Igwe, Gianna Kingsland, Maya Olofson, Jake Pacheco, Valeria Zamora-Collazos 
   
 Section 3:  Isabella Abreu, Khyla Cardona, Jack Deitch, Rose Eustache, Madelyn Franco, Tatyani Lawton, Larissa Levon-Zayas, Carly Malavarca, Yaw Mensah, Dev Montgomery, Donatella Salvia, Aseel Snober, Maurice Tobias 
   
   
 The Shape of Becoming BA Visual Arts Thesis Exhibition Finley Gallery, Finley Hall Exhibition dates: December 4-17, 2025 Closing Reception: Wednesday December 17, 6-8pm

title: Child Advocacy and Policy (MA) and Child Advocacy (Certificate) Virtual Information Session
description:
Lead Change in Child Advocacy and Policy   When children and families face complex challenges, they need informed, compassionate professionals to stand up, speak out, and shape solutions. If you're ready to turn your commitment into action, we're here to help.  We're hosting a  virtual information session on December 11 at 6:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Online Master of Arts in Child Advocacy and Policy 
 Child Advocacy (Certificate) – Online 
 
 Why Montclair?  Completing the certificate program allows you to transfer all 15 credits towards the Master of Arts in Child Advocacy, in accordance with all related graduate policy.

title: NIRSA + Montclair IM Sports Pickleball Tournament
description:

Grab your paddle, show off your skills, and battle it out on the courts. The Top 2 Winners won’t just claim victory - they’ll score a PAID trip to represent Montclair State University at the NIRSA Regional Pickleball Championships in Hamilton, NJ in January 2026!

 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Create or join a team on  IMLeagues.com/Montclairstate  and make payment at  rec.montclair.edu. 
 Fee is $10 per team. 
 Must be registered  before December 1st, 2025. 
 
 Where and When? 
 
 December 1-11, 2025 
 Student Recreation Center Gym

title: Visual Arts Thesis Exhibition: The Shape of Becoming
description:
Celebrate the end of the semester with a brilliant showcase from our rising Visual Arts graduates! This exhibition marks the culmination of their degree with each student presenting a cohesive body of artwork in the Finley Galleries, our final exhibition of the Fall 2025 semester. 
 The Shape of Becoming  features an impressive range of fresh perspectives and approaches: mixed-media sculpture, large-scale painting, textiles, video projection, and large-scale installations. 38 Visual Arts graduates invite you to explore their creative research and the questions driving their practice, on view through these vibrant capstone projects! title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: MBA, Dual Degrees, & Graduate Certificates Virtual Information Session
description: Designed for Where You Want to Go Next Montclair’s  MBA programs  are built for professionals who are ready to lead with purpose—and back it up with strategy. Whether you’re climbing higher in your current role or ready to pivot into something new, our flexible, career-focused curriculum will help you build the skills, confidence, and connections to make it happen.  Registration is open for our  virtual information session December 18 at 9:30 AM (EST) . Join us to explore our MBA pathways and find the one that aligns with your goals.

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on December 18  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

title: Isaac Mizrahi: A Holiday Fruitcake
description:
Actor, host, writer, designer, and producer Isaac Mizrahi “belongs to a brassy show business tradition running from Ethel Merman to Harvey Fierstein and including Liza Minnelli,” according to The New York Times. The creative multi-hyphenate’s one-of-a-kind holiday show features an eclectic mix of holiday classics, unexpected musical choices, and signature wit—blending humor, storytelling, and song. Accompanied by his six-piece jazz band, “Mizrahi is the real deal when it comes to cabaret: He’s charming, he sounds great, and he is seriously funny” (TheaterMania). 
 With a post-show holiday celebration including complimentary food and drinks in the lobby following the show!

title: Swipe Out Hunger
description:
As part of Montclair State University’s continuous commitment to eliminate student food insecurity, Auxiliary Services, Gourmet Dining, and the Office of the Dean of Students began investigating the implementation of a meal plan donation program. The goal also included getting the program recognized by the National Swipe Out Hunger network and establishing an ongoing collaboration with them. In January 2020, Montclair State became an official  Swipe Out Hunger Organization  campus partner. The university has once again teamed up with our resident dining provider, Gourmet Dining, to continue with The Swipe Out Hunger program encompassing both campuses, Montclair and Bloomfield, this semester. 
 Every Montclair State University or Bloomfield College student who is enrolled in a block meal plan (excluding unlimited meal plan holders) will be able to designate up to two (2) swipes per semester to the meal donation program. This drive will be active from October 20 until November 22. No additional meal swipes will be accepted after this date for the Fall 2025 semester.  Fill out this form  to make a difference!

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Magnificent Bird / Book of Travelers | Two Song Cycles written and performed by Gabriel Kahane
description:
Experience two distinct works by acclaimed songwriter and performer Gabriel Kahane in one unforgettable day.  
   
 In this duo of intimate solo musical plays, composer Gabriel Kahane blends songwriting and storytelling for a singular, poignant theatrical event. Book of Travelers recounts the strangers he met on a 9,000-mile train journey through a divided America, and Magnificent Bird chronicles a year he spent entirely off-line, and the unexpected turbulence of living quietly. Performed on alternating nights, these two concept albums offer a relentless self-inquiry, and a searing portrait of a world in flux.  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK. 
   
 Hailed as “one of the finest songwriters of the day” by The New Yorker, Gabriel Kahane is a musician and storyteller whose work spans the theater, club, and concert hall. Highlights of the 2024-25 season include a return to the New York stage in a production at Playwrights Horizons, performances at the Philharmonie de Paris, Wigmore Hall, and the Concertgebouw with fellow composer/performer Caroline Shaw, the premiere of a clarinet concerto for Anthony McGill, a solo debut with the Orchestre National de Lyon, and Kahane’s San Francisco conducting debut in Carla Kihlstedt’s Twenty-six Little Deaths. Kahane's collaborators range from Phoebe Bridgers, Paul Simon, Sufjan Stevens, and Sylvan Esso, to the Danish String Quartet, Roomful of Teeth, and Attacca Quartet. As a writer, he has been published by The New Yorker online and The New York Times; a newsletter and collection of essays on music, literature, and politics can be found at  gabrielkahane.substack.com . 
   
 4:00 pm Magnificent Bird 
 Run Time:  74 minutes, no intermission. 
   
 Magnificent Bird, is an intimate reflection on a year of self-imposed isolation during which the artist set out to write a song every day. With contributions from Andrew Bird, Chris Thile, Amelia Meath (Sylvan Esso), and Pulitzer Prize- winning composer Caroline Shaw, this collection explores the delicate balance between personal introspection and global crises. It’s a vivid musical snapshot of life during a tumultuous period, offering both a personal and universal meditation on modern-day existence. Based on Kahane’s fifth LP. 
   
 7:00 pm - Book of Travelers 
 Run Time:  70 minutes, no intermission 
   
 In Book of Travelers, Gabriel Kahane embarks on a journey across the United States, exploring the intersections of American identity and personal connection through the people he meets along the way. This powerful and emotional piece blends folk, classical, and pop influences to create a nuanced reflection on contemporary life in America. The work is a poignant and intimate exploration of what it means to traverse a country at a crossroads.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: I AM | Camille A. Brown & Dancers
description:
Five-time Tony nominated choreographer and director Camille A. Brown deepens her explorations of Black joy in Camille A. Brown & Dancers’  I AM . With captivating live and original music,  I AM  launches new queries into the possibilities of imagination—and boldly investigates the future. Inspired by a narrative within HBO’s  Lovecraft Country  and the rhythms of the movie  Drumline , Brown’s 2025 New York Times Critics’ Pick breaks boundaries and “takes her signature interweaving of African diasporic dance forms to new heights.” —  The New York Times 
   
  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

description:
Experience the iconic music of  RENT  like never before. In this sweeping symphonic concert produced by AMP Worldwide, a powerhouse ensemble of vocalists and instrumentalists brings Jonathan Larson’s groundbreaking rock musical to life in a sweeping symphonic concert. Featuring the full score—including “Seasons of Love,” “La Vie Bohème,” and “Take Me or Leave Me”—this electrifying performance celebrates the enduring spirit of love, loss, and chosen family. 
   
 Set in New York City’s East Village at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis,  RENT  follows a group of young artists as they chase their dreams, navigate heartbreak, and fight to live—and love—fully in the moment. Winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama,  RENT  remains a cultural touchstone with music that resonates across generations. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: ⭐ Honor Society Info Sessions (ALD, NSCS, Tau Sigma)
description: A Prestigious Scholarship is an academic or financial award given to outstanding students for graduate programs nationally and internationally. These scholarships often come with significant financial benefits, including full or partial tuition coverage, stipends for living expenses, and sometimes additional funds for research or travel. Join us to learn more about upcoming Prestigious Scholarship opportunities for the 2025-26 academic year.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Free Swim Clinics
description:
Take your swimming even further! Do you have a specific skill you really want to work on but never had the chance to, or that you have been meaning to learn? Each clinic will have its own topic to work on and really be able to go in-depth on. Skills include treading, flip turns, sprints, starts, and more.

 2/4 - Breaststroke 
 3/4 - Treading and Turns (flip turns and open turns) 
 4/1 - Butterfly

Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

organization: The Office for Experiential Education and Career Connections
description:
Looking to launch your career and gain experience through a full-time job or internship? The Office for Experiential Education and Career Connections invites students of all levels to network with employers in a wide variety of industries! 
 More Information : 
 
 Open to all students, alumni, and community members 
 Bring plenty of copies of your resume 
 Students must bring their Montclair State University Student IDs 
 Registration is required through Handshake. 
 
 March 18 1:00 PM -  4:00 PM

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Rocky's Closet at Bloomfield College Pop-Up
description:
We welcome all students who would like to add more clothing to their casual or professional wardrobe to our FREE pop-up shop!  XXS to XXL is the range of our sizes . Shop for as much as you want! 
 If you are interested in bringing your own clothing for other students as well, go for it! Be sure that the clothes don’t have holes or stains and are cleaned beforehand. 
 Psst, did I mention...EVERYTHING IS FREE!

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: ⭐ Honor Society Info Sessions (ALD, NSCS, Tau Sigma)
description: A Prestigious Scholarship is an academic or financial award given to outstanding students for graduate programs nationally and internationally. These scholarships often come with significant financial benefits, including full or partial tuition coverage, stipends for living expenses, and sometimes additional funds for research or travel. Join us to learn more about upcoming Prestigious Scholarship opportunities for the 2025-26 academic year.

title: Bench Press and Squat Competition
description:
Spring Strength Shadow! Welcome back to our annual Bench Press & Squat Competition. Come and test power and show your gains. Each event will feature 5 reps max. Whether you're chasing PRs or just want to flex for fun, this event is for you! Bring your friends and your lifting straps, and see who can lift their way to the top prize! 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Data: March 30th 
 Time: 3pm - 6pm 
 Student Recreation Center, Plae Room 
 
 How are results scored 
 
 Maximum 5 repetitions  
 1 attempt per lift after a warm up set 
 Scoring calculation: Weight lifted x repetitions divided by body weight  
 Final score will be a total of both lifts combined  
 
 Prizes :  
 
 Will be given to the top 3 winners  
 Tier 1: Beat Headphone ,  Fitness Watch ,  Air Fryer  $100-$200 
 Tier 2:  Massage Gun ,  Meal Prep Kit ,  Pilates Kit  $50-$100 
 Tier 3:  Foam Roller Set ,  Liquid IV ,  Owala Water Bottle  $20-$50 
 
 Free T-shirts - limited supply so show up early to claim one!

title: Free Swim Clinics
description:
Take your swimming even further! Do you have a specific skill you really want to work on but never had the chance to, or that you have been meaning to learn? Each clinic will have its own topic to work on and really be able to go in-depth on. Skills include treading, flip turns, sprints, starts, and more.

 2/4 - Breaststroke 
 3/4 - Treading and Turns (flip turns and open turns) 
 4/1 - Butterfly

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Denim Day 2026: Mind the Gaps, Move Forward
description:
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and together, we can break the silence.  The Montclair State University Police Department and the Office of Advocacy & Outreach are committed to fostering a campus where survivors feel heard, supported, and empowered.  It starts with believing. It starts with you.  By offering a safe and affirming response to those who disclose gender-based and sexual violence, we can create lasting change. Let’s stand together to end the cycle of silence—because  every voice matters, and every action counts. 
 Denim Day is recognized internationally as a day of action and awareness, encouraging people to wear denim to challenge victim-blaming and educate others about sexual violence.  This year, Denim Day falls on Wednesday, April 29, 2026. 
 The University Police and  Office of Advocacy & Outreach and the Office of Advocacy and Community Resilience , in partnership with over 30 campus and local community organizations, invites you to join us  from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. at the Amphitheater  for a powerful awareness event honoring survivors and increasing awareness of available resources. 
 Despite the  gaps  that still exist in the criminal justice system, in resources, and in prevention education,  we will move forward together  as a community. As part of this commitment, we will walk  one mile around campus in solidarity with survivors.
